I have also spoken about applied data visualization at Sundance, SXSW, Tribeca Film Institute, Stanford, MIT, the United Nations, and more. 
 
More info: www.ericdoversberger.com

Summary I was a founding member and Technical Program Lead on Google's Advanced Technology and Projects (ATAP) team, under the leadership of Regina E. Dugan, former DARPA executive director.  
 
At ATAP I led the Human/Social Dynamics program, an interdisciplinary laboratory pursuing projects which, broadly, bring us closer to the human heart: how, why, and what we feel. Our approach spans sociology, psychology, neuroscience, electrical engineering, machine learning, statistical, and phenomenological methods.  
 
I currently develop the technology we successfully incubated in ATAP within Google's larger organization. My approach to product management integrates data, research, software engineering, and behavioral models of product definition. I am committed to continuing ATAP's tradition of pragmatic innovation, coupled with Google's appetite for scale, efficiency, and global reach.  
 
I joined Google in 2008. In my former life, I authored a range of research projects including Project Oxygen—an influential study quantifying the impact of effective people management—featured in The New York Times, Harvard Business Review, and named one of HR Executive Magazines Most Innovative HR ideas in 2011.  
 
I give talks and consult with Chief HR Officers (CHROs) and other professionals. I have spoken at SHRM and advised firms like Frito Lay, Citibank, and others.  
 
I no longer work in talent management analytics, but it underscores my belief that technology and people are part of the same equation. As far back as 1906, sociologist Georg Simmel foretold that the sophistication of objective forms, such as products, gadgets, and media, has, will, and will continue to outpace the sophistication of our understanding of individual, subjective experience.  
 
In other words, many think the future is "out there" in tech entrepreneurship. I believe we must also use technology to look within: and what we find may be just as relevant to our technological (and societal) destiny.
